content:
Got this in Fastest.

Managed to solve the problem itself, but only got 71% because I couldn't format the numbers properly.

Looking at the other players who were with me in the Clash, it looks like we all had the same difficulties with formatting, since the scores are all 71% or 85%.

I spent more time on formatting than on the actual problem.
I tried rounding, I tried manually removing zeroes, I tried several pretty-printing formatting options, I tried to combine rounding with pretty-printing with manually trimming zeroes, and then the timer ran out and I still hadn't got  the number format you wanted.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I try the puzzle and it's fun, well explained, fun. A cool clash of code for me.
I think it is to hard to solve in under 15 minutes.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a nice challenge to set your teeth into. The statement is clear enough so that all time can be spent on coding up the solution. This is not a 'finished in 1 minute clash', which I like, because the longer coding, the more fun!

I really like this clash, but it feels a bit on the hard side to complete within 5 minutes. I only know Python and happen to know about itertools.permutations: does every language have such convenient access to permutations? I was able to complete in 5-6 minutes, but only because I use that import. I'd be happy to approve if someone can confirm that players of all languages should be able to get all permutations in under a minute.

And one remark: I accidentally wrote code that checked only for a better 'high'  value with A + B - C / D, and a better 'low'  value with A - B + C / D. Stupid of course (I should check for both high and low in both situations), BUT my code passed all tests except validator 4. In other words, could you make sure my code would also fail at a Test (not only at a Validator)? In a real clash I would have had no idea why I did not get 100%.
(7 9 0 3 is currently the only case in which the low  value is found with A + B - C / D. 6 9 0 3 would have the same behavior, so changing 'A Zero! Test' into 6 9 0 3 would do the trick.)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A little difficult, but doable in 4 minutes for me. And it was fun.

It is too complex for a Quick CoC. Maybe if you only keep the mode "Size of code", so people have more time to think? But then eval is still our friend...

Or you can give the hint that you gave below (only consider 'a+b-c/d' and 'a-b+c/d') so that people do not try to eval() anything ?
I think it's too hard for clash.

For anyone with an Android phone who wants to try this game, here's an app that someone made recently to play it against bots. It's very fun.

https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.SNGaming.com.unity.template.mobile2D&pli=1

* Please remove the duplicate upload.

* Would probably be a bit too difficult as a clash. Also favours a bit too much the languages with "eval" function - other language users have to write more code to take into account of the operator precedence.

* But this would make a nice Easy to Medium puzzle. Suggest you to change the type to puzzle instead.

Goal
* Suggest to change "true rules" to "full rules".

Constraints
* Suggest to delete the first constraint as it merely repeats what the input is.

* Suggest to change "one of the integers" to "one of the [[numbers]]".

* Suggest to remove the quotation marks.

Thanks.

Thanks as always, I've made the changes you suggest, but I'll keep it in WIP as a clash for now and see if others think it's too hard.

Once you've made the list of all permutations for the [[number]]s I think having 'eval' is not such a huge advantage, since if you just iterate through the permutations you could simply manually evaluate the results by just doing var1 + var2 - var3 / var4 and var1 - var2 + var3 / var4. You don't actually need to permute the operator positions as long as you test those two variations, since other permutations are redundant.

I might re-do my code without eval later, to confirm it's not too hard.

But if it's generally seen to be too hard, then I will submit as a puzzle with the full rules (which includes square root and multiplication operations). :)
I've added a hint which should make it easier to know what to do now.
Thanks for the tip. You're right, it's quite hard if you don't know there's only really two formulae to check and then all permutations of available numbers into each formula.

You don't happen to have the old code do you?
My code isn't written in a way to emulate that mistake easily, but I can get on that when I have a bit more time otherwise. Thanks for the bug report, I hate when I get 100% on tests but not validators!

Yeah, I can see this is on the hard side, but I figure that the number of permutations is only 24 (4!) for each of the 2 equations, so it shouldn't be too hard to just iterate through all permutations with either a recursive or iterative solution, i.e. without needing a function for permutations.

It's definitely harder than most clashes, but I'd say that the strongest clashers for this type of problem will still be able to solve it in 5 minutes without default libraries. Most people would need more like 15 minutes though, I agree.

Thanks for the feedback. I've tried to make the statement more clear and I've made it so that the rounding is without trailing 0's ("1.0" instead of "1.00" like before), which I think removes some of the unnecessary difficulty.

It's still not an easy puzzle, but once you understand the path to a solution I think most coders should be able to iterate through all the possibilities. With the hint I give them, I hope they will give solving it a try. :)

Otherwise, I can simplify it further and make it so that it's only the "Low" solution that needs to be solved in this clash, but I like the 'Hi-Lo' aspect a lot so I'll see what others think. No rejections so far and 2/3 approvals. But I hope my changes can quell your concerns it is too hard. Lmk if you think I should simplify further.
Thanks for the approving vote. I'm glad you liked it. :)
I suggest simplifying the output format. For instance, ask to always display the result with exactly two digits after the period, for instance 18.20 instead of 18.2, and 19.00 instead of 19.0.
Good suggestion. Implemented now.
I sent you my code through forum PM. I agree with the hard but doable part; I'm willing to approve once you included a test that results in the same as the validator for my stupid case.
Thanks, I've added a test case that fails for your code now (6 8 0 2) which is named "A + B - C / D". Glad to make the tests more robust!
Sounds great!

I would love to solve a puzzle with the full rules. 
I do agree that in the current format, especially by giving the hint that only two equations need to be solved, it is pretty much clash size and does not require eval.
